Physics Girl, I love you videos. You can reduce drag by putting a box around the box. The two boxes are not connected. The inside box should start at the top of the outside box. The outside drop experiences drag and therefore "shields" the inside box from drag. During the drop the inside box will move from the top of the outside box toward the bottom of the outside box. NASA does this in a 2.5 second drop tower at Glenn Research Center. As an intern I ran experiments there on candle flames in microgravity in the early 1990s. There is a book on this by Howard Ross, a NASA microgravity combustion scientist, https://www.amazon.com/Microgravity-Combustion-Fire-Free-Treatise/dp/0125981902.

a spherical flame is not caused by a lack of gravity, it is caused by a lack of buoyancy.
your flame went spherical due to aerodynamics (the air circulating as its motion changes). even if you make that box air-tight, and let it reach terminal velocity, you would not observe the effect you are describing. you cannot show this effect under any conditions of gravity. what you describe as "free fall" (terminal velocity) is not reached in this experiment at all, AND objects in a container falling at terminal velocity, experience gravity at 1g.. ie: if that candle could jump, it would fall back to the 'floor' of its box, even when the box is at terminal velocity because the box has stopped accelerating due to air drag, where the candle is still able to accelerate as it is not experiencing maximum air drag..

The phrase - "most of the air does gather at the bottom of the box" is not correct at all.
If you have a box that is 1l 10cmx10cmx10cm you will have 1.4g of air.
the surface of the bottom will be 100sq cm. The force exerted by pressure will be about 1000N
In order to compress the air with gravity to have at least twice the pressure at the bottom of such box you would need to have an acceleration which is equal to 1000N/0.0014kg = 714 000m/s^2
so if your box falls with the speed of 10m/s it has to stop in 14uS or come to a complete stop over a distance of 70microns.

[4:00] The gravity acting upon the ISS is practically the same as on the surface. The ISS is falling towards the Earth. It is not surprising that the effect is the same; the condition is the same.

Several people have mentioned that the container could be moving up and the effect of gravity would equally disappear. But if, as is often thought, gravity is whatever it is that moves things towards the earth (or, after Newton, towards other planets), and was the thinking in ancient times (but only because the Earth had already fallen to the center of the universe), then it becomes an irresolvable mystery that the effect of gravity could be nullified BOTH by something moving up AND something moving down, or for that matter, something neither moving up nor down.

The cleanest way out of the impasse is to just abandon the notion that I had even after taking basic courses in physics, complete with the appropriate math, in which I got A's, in which the teachers had better things to do then confound their students with such paradoxes. The first paradox about gravity I came to was in a popular book that introduced the extraordinary oddity that the laws of motion, even the outdated Newtonian version of gravity, are time reversible; only for the author to get to the topic of entropy. More interesting to me was a contradiction in my thinking: that if gravity in forward time was what tended to move things towards a mass, then gravity would tend to move things away if you played time backwards, as if a movie. I spent the next several weeks imagining time playing backwards in my imagination and confirming that real gravity looked the same in backwards time.

This brings me to a paradox which I noticed while thinking over this video. Gravity tends to disappear when the container is in free-fall, but not when the container is supported. And if the support were in free-fall, gravity in the container would also tend to disappear. Let us suppose the support were moving infinitesimally slower than container. Then it would be as if the container were supported. Imagining going from support to no support, then there must be some amount of time which it takes to go from one state to the other when the container is dropped. There can't really be a jump between two states

Hi Dianna,

I am a fan of your channel and I use your videos often to inspire girls in my physics class to dare do science. The one thing I would like to say is though that we physics teachers have a very hard time breaking down misconceptions, like when students think there is no gravity on the international space station. I know it is this awful misnomer that we call it microgravity, but I think it is best to avoid implying that weightlessness in orbit comes from "no gravity" and either just use the term weightlessness or explain the whole concept that weightlessness comes from falling around the earth in orbit.

Finally, you do inspire young students, not just girls, but probably girls even more to study science. Thank you!

At terminal velocity, the contents of the box would experience 1G, but it's a smooth ramp-up to the point, even at the relatively low speed you were dropping it at. . . I think. As far as I know this was first imagined by the kabbalist Hayim Vital in his work Etz Chayim. He describes how the flame if a candle would change once it reaches a point close to the orbit of the Moon, where it would no longer point up, nor would it give visible light.
In order to produce such an experiment we would have to be provided with a greater Delta V than that of any rocket ever built. But we understand this was a description of the L1 point, albeit 200 years before Lagrange.

To make the force of air resistance negligible, you could put the box inside of a larger box. Let the small box fall inside of the large box as the large box falls. Then the air that the small box travels through is also being accelerated downward and the air resistance will be many times smaller and constant. This is similar to the principle behind the design of the Gravity Probe B satellite.

@0:44 This isn't a micro-gravity situation. The ISS still experiences roughly the same acceleration due to gravity as we do here on the surface. So if anything the simulation with the box should be very close to the ISS as essentially both objects experience acceleration due to gravity and free fall.

Drag shield. You put a bigger box around that one, tie a string to the top of the tiny box, and pass it through a hole in the top of the big box. Hold the boxes by the string and then let go. The big box sees a large drag force. Within the frame of the big box, you effectively get a smaller value of g, and so the tiny box moves from the top of the big box to the bottom very slowly. Thus, you get a very small drag force on the tiny box.

I had a professor (Angel Abbud-Madrid) in college who developed a fire extinguisher which are currently used on the space station. You can't use a normal fire extinguisher because of the strange nature of fire in free fall. He had to do several drops like this in order to test the extinguisher, including going on the vomit comet. Eventually they managed to get a test of the extinguisher up on the ISS by one of the astronauts. The test data was on the Columbia shuttle when it disintegrated on re-entry. They thought the data was lost, but managed to salvage enough of it to get their results.

As a much, much younger man, I saw James Lovell giving a talk to my father's Masonic group (Lovell was a Mason. Probably still is). I took the opportunity to ask him a question afterwards, and it was "What would be the shape of a candle flame in space?" He seemed a bit surprised by the question (probably expecting the usual 'How do you poop in space?'), but answered it correctly, saying that it would be a sphere. I was immensely pleased with myself, because I had reasoned out the answer beforehand, and it felt nice to have it affirmed by someone knowledgeable.
It's almost as nice to be reminded of that occurrence by your experiment. Thanks!

"...falling towards the earth, pulled down by gravity, is just like floating out in space with no gravity at all." But the ISS isn't floating out in space with no gravity. Both the ISS and your box are in freefall! The only difference is the lack of air resistance up there and that they keep missing the earth, fortunately.

Also, while I'm on my soapbox, can we talk about the term "Microgravity". The ISS is being pulled towards earth with about 90% of the force felt at the surface. 90% is hardly "micro". Let's just call it what it is, freefall.

You won't need a teardrop shape; adding some stabilizing finds to the top will keep it oriented how you want. Adding weight to the bottom, alone,  won't do anything since the weight will act as part of the whole structure and be acted on be air resistance. Putting fins (think how the tail of a bomb is shaped) will guide the air and add more resistance at the tailing end without slowing it down much, thus keeping it upright.
